item.title: DAY 140 : From Holiday to Work
item.description:
A post for motivation recovery after 3 weeks of no internet and no smartphone holiday. As always, feeling that I do useless things…

I feel that the more I write, the more I got my motivation back to get my head in code. Just like before.

Is my work doing something great ? Am I an actor in doing something good ?

Does coding, programming do something useful ?

Surprisingly, I found myself to answer YES.

Humanity needs confidence and transparence. My sector has invented free software, Open source development. We, developers, are in the leading edge in inventing new business models, new ways of working, new ways of learning. It’s not perfect, and our market needs regulators to avoid new digital Moghuls doing business against our own interests.

The battle is here.

Getting back to work is like getting back to a war field. It needs courage and ambition.

The more I write, the more I got my motivation back.

Do you ?

item.title: DAY 120 : Refactoring code and integrate KVO
item.description:
In my first project, I had to display a ‘Update’ button each time a field value changed. And hide it, if not.

Now, I’d like to implement KVO mechanisms to avoid custom code and benefit from Apple API upgrades.

Let me remind you what is KVO.

KVO, as Key-Value Observer, is a way to observe value changes. Once implemented, you could associate actions.

Resources : http://www.appcoda.com/understanding-key-value-observing-coding/

item.title: DAY 120 : Learning Androïd development with Coursera
item.description:
I get my certificate from Coursera one week ago on ‘Programming Mobile Applications for Android Handheld Systems: Part 1’. My feedback about this course is positive, you should take it with the ‘signature track’. It costs 43€. The teacher is great, taking time on the basics that you need to know.

You could avoid the signature track, and do it freely. But as you pay, you’re under pressure and you pledge to finish the course. There were 4 weeks of 5 to 10 hours of study. Each week, you have to answer the quizz and submit a mini Androïd project. At the end, you will know : - How to create screens with UI elements - How to navigate between screens - How to build complex layout screen During the learning process, you will learn to use the IDE (Androïd Studio for my part), the simulator, the debugger. You will also have to launch JUnit tests.

At the end, you get several projects which will be your working template to develop more complex projects.

WATCH THE DATE : This course gives you extension time of 4-5 days for those who are late. It costs you 5% of your step score.

The last submission date has been a source of confusion. It interfered with the last quizz date. Many students have been trapped, thinking the last project submission date would be late after the last quizz date. As a general rule, don’t wait the last minute. Get some time to review the planning, even re-submit your project. Remember you will lose some valuable points if you miss the extension date.

Next : Programming Mobile Applications for Android Handheld Systems: Part 2 !!
